Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Functional Evolution of Sequence-specific DNA-binding Proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: An emerging lesson of modern biology is that living organisms cannot be understood as the sum of their component molecules but involve complex informational networks that behave as integrated systems. A second emerging lesson is that the biomolecular components themselves are not constant but change in structure and function during evolution. This project's research focuses on the functional evolution of important components of biomolecular networks, namely proteins that regulate gene expression by binding to certain patterns of nucleotide bases on double-stranded DNA. In a functionally diverse family of microbial DNA-binding proteins called Cro, analysis of databases suggested an "evolutionary code", whereby the preferences of the protein for single bases in target DNA appeared to evolve through simple, single amino-acid changes in the protein. The project involves testing the limits of this simple code by parallel application of site-directed mutagenesis, binding affinity measurements, binding site selection, and structural biology to diverse Cro proteins. These studies also include assessment of the contribution of more complex and subtle factors to functional evolution, such as evolutionary changes in protein structure. The educational portion of the project emphasizes opportunities for undergraduate research as a critical element in the development of a new generation of scientists, and incorporation of computer lab facilities in graduate-level teaching to facilitate a transition between classroom study and independent research. Broader impacts include development of the infrastructure for research and education through enhancement and use of computer lab facilities, increased opportunities for research experiences for undergraduates and students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Underlying the visible behavior and development of cells and organisms are complex gene regulatory systems at the nanoscale level.  These systems are based on interactions between protein and DNA molecules. The effective operation of such regulatory systems depends on a diversity of DNA-binding proteins specifically tailored to bind to certain regions of DNA.  This project investigates how the diverse function of DNA-binding proteins arises from evolutionary processes.  For example, it is possible that a protein can evolve to target a new region of DNA simply through genetic mutations to change amino acids in the protein that make specific contacts to the DNA. It is also possible that a protein can change its function through more general changes in its structure. 

To investigate these possibilities, we chose a family of viral DNA-binding proteins called Cro.  The Cro family is "hyperdiverse" in both structure and function, making it a good system to explore the pathways for evolving the known diversity of DNA-binding protein functions.  We have found that the evolution of Cro proteins follows, at least in part, an "evolutionary code" composed of a combination of a few very simple genetic mutations. We also found that major changes in Cro protein structure were, perhaps surprisingly, actually fairly neutral with respect to the evolution of function.  One lesson that emerges from this work is that it is possible for protein structure to drift quite far during evolution while preserving a similar function. This result contrasts with a historical view that preserving the function of a protein depends on preserving a particular type of structure, or "fold".

The project also includes broader impacts at the level of education and training in STEM fields. We have implemented novel curricular elements for undergraduate Biochemistry classes as well as for graduate-level structural biology classes. On the undergraduate level, we developed a series of weekly "guided inquiries" for implementation in a small discussion setting. In addition, we specifically incorporated evolutionary themes into many of these discussions, for example the analysis of dinosaur protein samples and the evolution of virus-host recognition.  On the graduate level, we developed computer lab procedures for hands-on exploration of techniques for determining protein and DNA structure. Finally, a variety of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups, including Native American, African-American and Hispanic, have been trained to do biochemical research in conjunction with this project, helping to increase the diversity of researchers entering science fields.
